qas.question: How big a part did symbiosis have in the development of flowering plants and their pollinators?
What did some plants produce when flowers became less simple?
What is the word for the kind of relationship in which a plant depend on a single type of insect?
What gave rise to a select group of plants?
What flowering plants in the fossil record had relatively complex flowers?
What did bats develop to access and collect these rich food sources?
What did birds develop to access and collect these rich food sources?
What animals need to be modified in order to be correspondingly adapted?

context: Symbiosis played <a0_0>a major role<a0_0/> in the co-evolution of flowering plants and the animals that pollinate them. Many plants that are pollinated by <b7_0>insects, bats, or birds<b7_0/> have highly specialized flowers modified to promote pollination by a specific pollinator that is also correspondingly adapted. <b4_0>The first<b4_0/> flowering plants in the fossil record had relatively simple flowers. <b3_0>Adaptive speciation<b3_0/> quickly gave rise to many diverse groups of plants, and, at the same time, corresponding speciation occurred in certain insect groups. Some groups of plants developed <a1_0>nectar and large sticky pollen<a1_0/>, while insects evolved more <b5_0><b6_0>specialized morphologies<b6_0/><b5_0/> to access and collect these rich food sources. In some taxa of plants and insects the relationship has become <a2_0>dependent<a2_0/>, where the plant species can only be pollinated by one species of insect.
